subSections.title: Alternative forms
subSections.text:
* {{l|mul|犭}} (when used as a left Chinese radical)

Although the alternative form clearly shows only three strokes, it is still counted as four strokes when using a Chinese dictionary. Compare [[氵]] from {{m|mul|水||water|sc=Hani}}, [[扌]] from {{m|mul|手||hand|sc=Hani}}, and [[忄]] from {{m|mul|心||heart|sc=Hani}}, all of which are a 3-stroke form from a 4-stroke character.

subSections.title: Glyph origin
subSections.text:
{{Han etyl}}
{{liushu|p}} The side view of a [[dog]].

subSections.title: Etymology
subSections.text:
From {{inh|zh|sit-pro|*d-kʷəj-n||dog}}.

This common Sino-Tibetan word has been replaced by {{och-l|狗}} in most dialects except Min Dong, such as [[w:Fuzhou dialect|Fuzhou]] ''kēng''. In other dialects, this word is mainly found in compounds and not used alone.

subSections.title: Readings
Compounds
Etymology
subSections.text:
{{wikipedia|lang=ja}} {{wikipedia|Dog}} [[File:Coat_types_3.jpg|thumb|250px|{{lang|ja|犬}} (''inu''): various kinds of '''[[dog]]'''.]]
{{ja-kanjitab|いぬ|yomi=k}} From {{etyl|ojp|ja|sort=いぬ}}. Derivation uncertain. Various theories exist, including derivation from ancient verb {{m|ja|往ぬ|tr=inu||to leave, to be gone}}, from the way a dog will guard the house while the master is away; from a compound of {{m|ja|家|tr=ie||house, home}} + {{m|ja|寝|tr=nu||to sleep|pos=ancient monosyllabic form of modern {{m|ja|寝る}} ''neru''}}; from ancient Japanese {{m|ja|狗|tr=enu||puppy, dog}}, itself of uncertain derivation; or as a borrowing from some other unknown language.

subSections.title: Noun
Derived terms
subSections.text:
* {{l|ko|犬公}} ([[견공]], ''gyeongong'') (''personification'')
* {{l|ko|犬馬}} ([[견마]], ''gyeonma'') [[dog]] and [[horse]]
* {{l|ko|犬儒}} ([[견유]], ''gyeonyu'') [[cynic]]
* {{l|ko|犬猿}} ([[견원]], ''gyeonwon'') [[dog]] and [[monkey]]
* {{l|ko|猛犬}} ([[맹견]], ''maenggyeon'') fierce dog
* {{l|ko|愛犬}} ([[애견]], ''aegyeon'') pet dog
* {{l|ko|鬪犬}} ([[투견]], ''tugyeon'') fighting dog
